clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Oral Carbohydrate on Serum S-100β Protein and Development of Postoperative Delirium in Elderly Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Oral Carbohydrate on Serum S-100β Protein and Development of Postoperative Delirium in Elderly Patients

brief_summary.textblock: This study is to evaluate the effects of preoperative carbohydrate intake on perioperative neuroinflammation and development of delirium.

detailed_description.textblock: Perioperative insulin resistance may primarily contribute to development of postoperative delirium in high risk patients. Preoperative administration of oral carbohydrate reduces insulin resistance. The investigators aimed to investigate the influence of carbohydrate loading on the serum level of S-100β, a surrogate marker of delirium, and the incidence of postoperative delirium in elderly patients.

study_design_info.masking: Double Blind (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

arm_group.description: Patients was administered in hospital Randomization Patient was allocated to Carbohydrated group Patients received 400 mL of oral isotonic glucose (No NPO®, Daesang, Korea) 12 hours before anesthesia and 400 mL 2 hours before. CHL composition was standard: 12.5 g of carbohydrate per 100 mL, 12% monosaccharide, 12% disaccharide, 76% polysaccharide, 250 mOsm/kg and 50 kcal.
Patients was administered in hospital Randomization Patient was allocated to Placebo group Patients received 400 mL of water 12 hours before anesthesia and 400 mL 2 hours before anesthesia.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoing total hip replacement or total knee replacement surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diabetes
- Dementia
- Gastro-esophageal reflux
- Upper gastrointestinal motility disorder
- Inflammatory bowel disease
- Intraperitoneal malignancy history
- Inability to perform cognitive function test
